indicator.title: Output Indicator

baseline.comment: - Crisis and Recovery Mapping and Analysis (CRMA) exercise completed in West Darfur state and reports and maps produced; but no village specific CRMA exercise - No Conflict assessment conducted in any of the four return villages in West Darfur State -Widespread destruction of livelihoods and productive assets in most villages in Darfur during the 9 years of the conflict; - No adequate support has been provided -Widespread destruction of basic community infrastructure,no adequate support has been provided. -No formal/ organised structures for coordinating / managing villages’ assets

actual.comment: 1.1) CRMA exercises were completed in four target villages and 21 key livelihoods and infrastructure interventions identified and implemented (see output 3). A gender disaggregated report including four (4) community resource maps and 4 development maps and plans were produced as an outcome of the CRMA exercises. Some 95% of the community resource persons involved in the process stated that they are now able to identify risks and needs and as well as identifying resources and opportunities to improve livelihoods and community development. 1.2) Conflict assessment and analysis were conducted in the four target villages. Key risk factors and conflict flash points were identified through the exercise. The exercise identified the risk of conflicts from the competition over limited natural resources and basic services such as water, fuelwood, grinding mills, grazing and agricultural land and conflict between nomads and sedentary farmers in the return villages. It also highlighted the distances to key resources and the risk to women. As a result appropriate interventions were identified, planned and implemented. 2.1) 769 vulnerable HHs in 4 villages now own and use productive assets such as donkey carts, treadle pumps, goats, and seeds and tools as a result of the Project. Details of the assets provided are listed in the table 1 and 2 above. 2.2) Some 513 HHs own and use fuel efficient stoves through the support of the Project. Out of these, 158 people have been trained as trainers in the production of fuel efficient stoves and in turn, they have trained up to 435 beneficiaries of which 86% were women. 3.1 Twenty One (21) community infrastructures were rehabilitated/ constructed and used. These include:  1 water pump constructed, 3 water pumps were rehabilitated, 2 hand dug- well constructed;  4 markets were rehabilitated;  7 grinding mills made available  1 oil extracting machine established and used;  1 storage facility was constructed  One building with 3 ro

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.Number of Peace and Development Councils established and effective in their function

target.comment: 1.1. 5 additional CBRM councils functional, including in Katila 1.2 50 % of community members have access to CBRMs 1.3: Project target 90% 1:4: Project target 80% 1.5: At least 1 representative of vulnerable groups in each CBRM 2.1: 5 community based management mechanisms for natural resources estab-lished 2.2: at least 5 social service infrastructure rehabilitated /newly built 2.3: 50 % of community members stating an increase in the number of interactions between diverse communities through basic services 2.4 At least 3 community social service infrastructure rehabilitated/ constructed. 3.1: 1 collective interactions of conflict resolution mechanisms with state and regional level mechanisms 3.2: 3 collective interactions of conflict resolutions mechanisms with higher level mechanism

actual.comment: Target 1.1: Four (4) new Peace Development Councils were established within the year: one in Idd el Fursan and one in Ku-bum, as well as two (2) sub committees in Kubum. Additional two PDCs will be established in Katilla in the Q1 2015. This brings to a total of 14 PDCS formed since the project started in January 2012. The capacity of PDC members was strengthened through 2 training workshops on conflict management and community planning. The trainings have built the confidence of the mem-bers and the councils are now operating with minimal backstop-ping from the DCRC team. Target 1.2 & 1.3: Within 2014, 100% of the disputes submitted to the PDCs were successfully resolved and settled. The PDCs resolved approximately 45 cases and became accessible by 100% of all the community members. Target 1.4: The project conducted a perception survey in Mukjar, Kubum and Idd Elfursan and as a result over 80% of commu-nity members who were interviewed reported that the project activities positively supported the restoration of trust and confi-dence. Target 1.5: Reported from PDCs: • Salamat tribe: 2 • Four tribe: 4 • Bani Halba: 5 • Women: 5 • Young male:2 • Young female: 2 • Bargo tribe: 1 • Hawsa: 2 • IDPs: 4 2.1: Internal review and workshops were conducted and 5 new areas for the community based management mechanisms for natural re-sources were identified. Through the comprehen-sive discussion with PDCs and the IPs, rehabilita-tion of 2 water points, 2 veterinary centres and construction of vegetable farms and water points were initiated and prioritised. 2.2: A total of 6 community improvement projects were completed in all three states within 2014. In Tawilla, implementation delayed due to the poor performance of the IP in North Darfur, new IP selected and the project made some good progress on the ground. With the no cost extension received, extending the duration of the project to the end of June 2014, the project succeeded to achieve 95% of this output. 2.3: Focus g

target.comment: 1.1 5 additional CBRM councils functional, including in Katila 1.2 50 % of community members have access to CBRMs of which at least 40% are female and vulnerable youth. 2.1 5 community based management mechanisms for natural resources established 2.2 At least 5 community social service infrastructure rehabilitated/ constructed 2.3 50 % of community members stating an increase in the number of interactions between diverse communities through basic services 3.1 3 collective interactions of conflict resolution mechanisms with state and regional level mechanisms 3.2 3 collective interactions of conflict resolutions mechanisms with higher level mechanism

location.name: El Fasher
location.description: seat of a first-order administrative division

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Increase in revenue collection 2. Number of institutions at state and locality level with computerized payroll system 3. Number of SSP reviewed and prioritized for three states

baseline.comment: 1. Local revenue too low amounting to only 15% (ND), 20% (SD) and 3.5% (WD) of total revenue receipts in 2009 (ND) and 2010 (SD & WD). 2. No Standard guidelines for revenue collection and reporting in place. 3. Budget departments facing difficulties to apply the GFS as it was imposed from the national Government without provision of requisite training. 4. Payroll is done manually resulting in errors and huge payroll arrears. 5. Strategic planning is still at its infancy and therefore needs strengthening.

target.comment:
1. Revenue collection & Reporting 1.1 100 booklets/guidelines developed & distributed to localities 1.2 10 teams applying GFS system in selected localities for the year.
2. Budget preparation & Management 2.1 20 line ministries & 10 selected localities prepare GFS conform budget. 2.2 90 staff from line ministries and pilot localities trained on GFS.
3. Accounting & reporting systems developed 3.1 40% at line ministries & 20% at localities level decrease in reporting inconsistencies 3.2 20 line ministries & 10 selected localities apply the adopted GFS system after training.
4. Payroll Management & Control 4.1 5 State Ministries of Finance equipped with computerized payroll system 4.2 5 payroll audits conducted
5. Planning & local development fund 5.1 SSP 2012-2016 reviewed for three states & new SSP prepared for 2 states. 5.2 Guide for Strategic Planning Developed & 100 copies distributed 5.3 200 staff trained

actual.comment: 297 participants were exposed to principles of improved revenue collection and reporting The guidelines on financial procedure and budgeting processes were produced in West Darfur and were distributed to stakeholders. 40% at line ministries and 20% at localities level decreased in reporting inconsistencies 20 line ministries and 10 selected localities applied the adopted GFS system Three State ministries equipped and automated payroll system functional. The total number of staff trained in various aspects of project planning, management and evaluation was 226 (79 females and 147 males), exceeding the annual target of 200. In West Darfur, a payroll audit team has been established and payroll audit conducted

target.comment:
Output 1 10% increase in local revenue collection 100 booklets/guidelines developed & distributed to localities 10 teams applying GFS system in selected localities for the year
Output 2 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities prepare GFS conforming budget 90 staff from line ministries and pilot localities trained on GFS.
Output 3 20% of line ministries and 20% of localities level decrease in reporting inconsistencies 10 line ministries and 10 selected localities apply the adopted GFS system
Output 4 5 State Ministries of Finance equipped with computerized payroll system and routinely using it 1 audit conducted 20% decrease in payroll arrears
Output 5 Guide for strategic planning developed & 100 copies distributed 200 staff at state and locality levels trained on strategic planning process.

actual.comment: Two preliminary audits were undertaken in West and South Darfur

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1.1 # of community management committees (CMCs), local reconciliation and dialogue forum, and community based conflict resolution mechanisms functioning effectively 1.2 # of communities reached through the sensitization campaigns on peace, reconciliation, SALW control and prevention of violence against women and youth 1.3 % of composition of youth, women, IDPs, pastoralists and other vulnerable groups in the CMC 1.4 # of initiatives of SARCOM action plan of 2015 and # of Arms Registration and Marking Committees’s action plan identified for implementation 2.1: # of Participatory assessment conducted and men and women’s needs identified in target locations 2.2: # of infrastructure/livelihoods projects addressing security,NRM and livelihood issues implemented in target communities 2.3: # of male and female community members directly or indirectly benefiting from the infrastructure projects 3.1.# local governmental institutions successfully support to deliver services in target communities 3.2. # local non-governmental institutions successfully delivering services in target communities. 4.1 Number of M&E field visits conducted 4.2 Number of reports submitted

baseline.comment:
1.1 (2014) Zero 1.2 (2014) two 1.3 (2014) TBC 1.4 (2014) Two (2) activities supported for Sub-regional Arms Control Mechanism and two (2) state levels Arms Registration and Marking Committees established 2.1 (2014) Zero. 2.2 2 (2014) Zero 2.3 (2014) 6,000 indirect beneficiaries in the target locations. 3.1.(2014) Zero 3.2. (2014) 31 NGOs/CBOs identified in Darfur having minimum capacity to engage with CSAC projects.
4.1. 0 4.2. no (annual and biannual) report in 2014 submitted as the project is newly established

target.comment:
5.1 Programme Implementation Guidelines/manual/SOPs that includes PI, M&E, gender mainstreaming tools and methodologies developed and used 5.2 At least 50 % of operational support for successful implementation in the three Darfur field offices in terms of staff, office logistics, IT, administrative etc. provided.
5.3 At least four case stories developed and shared each quarter -5.4 At least one Project Review Meeting conducted in 2015. 5.5. Risks and issues updated quarterly for the project

actual.comment: 5.1. Drafted 5.2.1.Staff members are deployed and providing reintegration briefing services 5.2.2.NGOs capacity assessments conducted. 5.2.3. Furnitures procured for the offices in North Darfur 5.3.Reintegration activities have not started, no stories developed/shared 5.4. To be held in Q3 5.5. on progress

iati-activity.title: TB
iati-activity.description: WHO estimated that in 2012, the prevalence of TB was approximately 207/100,000 and mortality due to TB was 22/100,000. According to the preliminary results of the 2013 TB prevalence survey, the prevalence of positive TB cases was 136 per 100,000.
